Comments_List: Taught how to do conduction improvisation and taught about its history and social impacts

I previously knew almost nothing about experimental jazz, so I learned a lot about the genre and about the way its produced. I appreciated that Professor Veal emphasized ensemble rehearsal because the best way to learn is to try.
History and culture behind jazz and contemporary extensions
Improvisation and conducting techniques, how to work with other members of a small ensemble.

Strength: meets once a week, opens your perspectives, gives you new ideas of music and beauty, teaches you to compare art and architecture to class, only one interesting final paper
Weakness: none!

I thought it was really helpful to listen back to Conductions and discuss them as a class--both the Conductions we produced and the ones for assigned listening. I would like to have done that more often. Other than that, I was glad that most of our class time was dedicated to practicing. Definitely a must for this type of music.
Chill course, but needs more people to truly bring out the conduction ensemble effect and feel.
Absolutely- low workload, low time commitment, interesting, and you get to perform in an ensemble for credit! It will change your view of sound and life
This course is unlike any other I took this year.  I would recommend it because it forces musicians to take risks, have courage, and try a new form of music.
Yes! Fun course and the professor is very knowledgeable about experimental music and conducting.
